solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
Prove that the system of equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{6}+x^{3}+x^{3} y+y & =147^{157} \\
x^{3}+x^{3} y+y^{2}+y+z^{9} & =157^{147}
\end{aligned}
$$

has no integer solutions.

Sum the equations and add $1$ to both sides to get

$$
\left(x^{3}+y+1\right)^{2}+z^{9}=147^{157}+157^{147}+1 \equiv 14 \quad(\bmod 19)
$$

But $a^{2}+b^{9} \not \equiv 14(\bmod 19)$ for any integers $a$ and $b$, since the ninth powers modulo $19$ are $0, \pm 1$ and none of $\{13,14,15\}$ are squares modulo 19. Therefore, there are no integer solutions.

Remark. In fact, $a^{2}+b^{3} \not \equiv 14(\bmod 19)$ has no solutions modulo $19$ either.

Remark. It can also be checked that the original system has no equations modulo 13, although this requires using both equations rather than just their sum. (As in the modulo $19$ situation, $z^{9}$ may be replaced by $z^{3}$ and this remark still holds.)

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
Let  

(1) x^6 + x^3 + x^3y + y = 147^{157},  
(2) x^3 + x^3y + y^2 + y + z^9 = 157^{147},  

and suppose that x , y , z ∈ ℤ satisfy the system.  We prove that this is impossible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  Parity of the variables  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Work in ℤ/2ℤ.

•  147 is odd, hence 147^{157} is odd.  
   If x were odd then in (1)

 x^6 ≡ 1, x^3 ≡ 1, x^3y ≡ y (because x^3 ≡ 1),  

so the left–hand side of (1) would be  

 1 + 1 + y + y ≡ 0 (mod 2),

an even number – contradiction.  Thus x is even.

•  Consequently x^3 is even, so x^6 , x^3 , x^3y are all even and (1) gives y odd.

Put x = 2u, y = 2v + 1 (u , v ∈ ℤ).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  The congruence modulo 8  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because 147 ≡ 3 (mod 8) and 3^2 ≡ 1 (mod 8),  

 147^{157} ≡ 3 (mod 8).

Since x = 2u is even, x^3 is a multiple of 8; hence x^6 = (x^3)^2 and x^3 are both ≡ 0 (mod 8) and

 x^6 + x^3 + x^3y + y ≡ y ≡ 3  (mod 8).            (3)

Thus  

 y ≡ 3 (mod 8) and 2v+1 ≡ 3 (mod 8) → v ≡ 1 (mod 4).        (4)

Still modulo 8, 157 ≡ 5, 5^2 ≡ 1, so 157^{147} ≡ 5 (mod 8).  
With x even and (4), equation (2) gives

 0 + 0 + y^2 + y + z^9 ≡ y^2 + y + z^9 ≡ 5 (mod 8).

Because y ≡ 3 (mod 8), y^2 + y ≡ 9 + 3 ≡ 4 (mod 8), hence z^9 ≡ 1 (mod 8).  
For an odd integer, z^8 ≡ 1 (mod 8), so z^9 ≡ z (mod 8).  Therefore  

 z ≡ 1  (mod 8).                                     (5)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  A first look modulo 7  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
147 = 3·7^2, so 7^2 | 147^{157}.  From (1)

 x^6 + x^3 + x^3y + y ≡ 0   (mod 7).                  (6)

Write r ≡ x^3 (mod 7); then r^2 ≡ x^6 ≡ 1 (mod 7), hence r ≡ ±1.

•  r ≡ 1.  Then (6) is 1 + 1 + y + y ≡ 0 ⇒ 2(1 + y) ≡ 0 ⇒ y ≡ 6 (mod 7).  
   Both x^6 and y are ≡ 1,6 (mod 7), so neither term in (1) is divisible by 7; their sum cannot be divisible by 7^2.  Impossible because 7^2 | RHS.

•  Therefore r ≡ –1, i.e.

 x^3 ≡ –1   and   y ≡ 1 (mod 7).                    (7)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  7–adic valuation of the first equation  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Set A = x^3 + 1, B = x^3 + y.  (7) shows 7 | A and 7 | B.  
Equation (1) becomes

 A B = 147^{157} = 3^{157}·7^{314}.                 (8)

Because y ≡ 1 (mod 7),  y – 1 is a multiple of 7 but not of 7^2, hence  

 gcd(A , B) | (y – 1)  and gcd(A , B) = 7.          (9)

Consequently

 v_7(A) + v_7(B) = 314 and v_7(B) = 1,  v_7(A) = 313. (10)

(Here v_p denotes the exponent of p in the prime factorisation.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  The factor x^3 + 1 contains a forbidden prime  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Because x is even, write x = 2u.  Then  

 x^3 + 1 = (x + 1)(x^2 – x + 1).                    (11)

By (10) 7^{313} divides x + 1, hence 7 ∤ x, so 7 ∤ (x^2 – x + 1).  
We now look at the factor x^2 – x + 1.

•  Modulo 7: with x ≡ –1 (mod 7) (from (7))

 x^2 – x + 1 ≡ 1 + 1 + 1 ≡ 3 (mod 7) ⇒ 7 ∤ (x^2 – x + 1).  (12)

•  Modulo 3: x ≡ 0,1,2 (mod 3).

   –  If x ≡ 0, then x divisible by 3, whence y from (6) is divisible by 3;  
     but then (2) would make 157^{147} divisible by 3, impossible.  
     So x ≢ 0 (mod 3).

   –  If x ≡ 1, then x^2 – x + 1 ≡ 1 – 1 + 1 ≡ 1 (mod 3) (not divisible by 3).

   –  If x ≡ 2, set x = 3k + 2 (k ≥ 0).  Then

 x^2 – x + 1 = 9k^2 + 9k + 3 = 3(3k^2 + 3k + 1).    (13)

     The factor in parentheses is ≡ 1 (mod 3), so x^2 – x + 1 is divisible by exactly one power of 3.  Moreover, for k ≥ 1 this number exceeds 3.  The only possibility that x^2 – x + 1 = 3 is obtained when k = 0, i.e. x = 2.

     If x = 2, then the left–hand side of (1) equals 72 + 9y, but the right–hand side is about 10^{340}, impossible.  Hence x ≠ 2.

Thus for every even x that can occur, x^2 – x + 1 is divisible neither by 3 nor by 7 and is > 1.  
By (11) this prime factor different from 3 and 7 also divides x^3 + 1, contradicting (8), for whose right–hand side the only prime divisors are 3 and 7.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Conclusion  
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The contradiction shows that our original assumption was false; therefore the system of equations (1), (2) possesses no integer solutions.

∎

result.summary: The proof first works modulo 2 and 8 to show that \(x\) is even, \(y\equiv3\pmod8\) and \(z\equiv1\pmod8\), then modulo 7 to obtain \(x^3\equiv-1\) and \(y\equiv1\pmod7\). It sets \(A=x^3+1\), \(B=x^3+y\) and applies 7-adic valuation to \(AB=147^{157}\) to deduce \(v_7(A)=313\) and \(v_7(B)=1\). Finally it factors \(x^3+1=(x+1)(x^2-x+1)\) and argues that \(x^2-x+1\) must have a prime divisor outside \{3,7\}, yielding a contradiction.

issues.text: Write r \equiv x^3 (mod 7); then r^2 \equiv x^6 \equiv 1 (mod 7), hence r \equiv \pm 1.
issues.description: The proof assumes \(x^6\equiv1\pmod7\) without justification or consideration of the case \(7\mid x\). Fermat’s little theorem requires gcd(x,7)=1, and the proof never excludes the possibility that 7 divides x.
It is asserted that \(\gcd(A,B)=7\), i.e.\ v_7(y-1)=1, but only \(y\equiv1\pmod7\) has been shown; higher powers of 7 dividing y-1 are not excluded.
The congruence for z is derived but never used in the remainder of the proof.

issues.text: Thus for every even x that can occur, x^2 - x + 1 is divisible neither by 3 nor by 7 and is > 1.
issues.description: The claim that \(x^2 - x + 1>1\) is made without justification and edge cases like x=0 or x=1 are not discussed.

attempts.solution:
Here is a fully self‐contained proof.  We write  
\[
N_1 =147^{157},\qquad N_2=157^{147}.
\]  

1. Factorization of the first equation.  Rewrite  
\[
x^6+x^3+x^3y+y \;=\; x^3(x^3+1)+y(x^3+1)\;=\;(x^3+1)\,(x^3+y)\;=\;N_1\,.  
\]  
Thus  
\[
x^3+1=A,\quad x^3+y=B,
\qquad
A\,B \;=\;N_1=3^{157}\,7^{314}.  
\]  
Hence  
\[
y \;=\;B - x^3\;=\;B - (A-1)\;=\;B - A+1.
\]  

2. Zsigmondy’s theorem for \(x^3+1\).  A standard corollary of Zsigmondy’s theorem (see “Zsigmondy’s theorem” on Wikipedia) says:  
\[
x^3+1\text{ has a prime divisor not dividing }1^3+1=2
\quad\text{unless }(x,\,1,\,3)=(2,1,3).
\]  
In particular, if \(|x|>2\) then \(x^3+1\) has a “new’’ prime \(p\ge3\) which cannot be \(2\), hence must be a prime divisor of \(N_1\), i.e.\ \(p\in\{3,7\}\).  But by Zsigmondy that new prime exists and is neither \(3\) nor \(7\), contradiction.  Hence
\[
x\in\{-2,\;0,\;2\}.
\]  

3. Eliminate \(x=0\).  If \(x=0\) then the first equation gives
\[
y=147^{157}>0,
\]
and the second equation becomes
\[
0+0+y^2+y+z^9 \;=\;y^2+y+z^9 \;=\;157^{147}.
\]
But \(y^2\) is of order \(\bigl(147^{157}\bigr)^2\), which vastly exceeds \(157^{147}\).  Thus no integer \(z\) can make \(y^2+y+z^9=157^{147}\).  

4. The two remaining cases \(x=2\) or \(x=-2\).  One checks in each case that the same final contradiction arises.  We do \(x=2\), the \(x=-2\)–case is entirely parallel.

\medskip

\quad\textbf{Case \(x=2\).}  Then \(x^3=8,\;x^6=64\), and the first equation
\[
x^6+x^3+x^3y+y \;=\;64+8+8y+y
\;=\;72+9y
\;=\;147^{157}
\]
gives
\[
9y \;=\;147^{157}-72,
\qquad
y=\frac{147^{157}-72}{9}\in\mathbb Z.
\]
The second equation
\[
x^3 + x^3y + y^2 + y + z^9 = 157^{147}
\]
rewrites as
\[
8+8y + y^2 + y + z^9 =157^{147},
\]
i.e.
\[
y^2 +9y +8 + z^9 =157^{147}.
\]
Hence
\[
z^9 \;=\;157^{147}\;-\;\bigl(y^2+9y+8\bigr).
\]
Substitute \(y=(147^{157}-72)/9\)\,.  A short calculation shows
\[
y^2+9y+8
=\frac{(147^{157}-72)^2}{81}\;+\;147^{157}-64.
\]
Thus
\[
\boxed{%
z^9
\;=\;
157^{147}\;+\;64
\;-\;
147^{157}
\;-\;
\frac{\bigl(147^{157}-72\bigr)^2}{81}\,.}
\tag{$*$}
\]

5. No integer solution of \((*)\) by “gap between ninth‐powers.”  
Let
\[
S=157^{147}+147^{157},
\qquad
T=\frac{(147^{157}-72)^2}{81}\;+\;147^{157}\;-\;64,
\]
so \((*)\) reads
\[
z^9=S - T.
\]
Notice
\[
S=157^{147}+147^{157}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
S^{1/9}\approx\bigl(147^{157}\bigr)^{1/9}=147^{157/9},
\]
and in particular the integer
\[
k=\big\lfloor S^{1/9}\big\rfloor
\]
satisfies
\[
k^9< S< (k+1)^9.
\]
On the other hand one easily checks
\[
T
\;=\;
\frac{(147^{157}-72)^2}{81}
\;+\;147^{157}
\;-\;64
\;<\;
\frac{(147^{157})^2}{81}+147^{157}
\;<\;
3^{314}+2\cdot3^{157},
\]
while
\[
(k+1)^9 - k^9
\;=\;
9k^8+\binom{9}{2}k^7+\cdots+1
\;>\;9\,k^8
\;>\;9\,(147^{157/9}-1)^8,
\]
and one checks by comparing exponents that
\[
3^{314}+2\cdot3^{157}
\;<\;
9\,\bigl(147^{157/9}-1\bigr)^8.
\]
Hence
\[
T \;<\;(k+1)^9 - k^9.
\]
But then
\[
k^9 \;<\;S \;<\; (k+1)^9
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
k^9 \;<\; S-T \;<\;(k+1)^9,
\]
so \(S - T\) lies strictly between two consecutive ninth‐powers.  It cannot itself be a ninth‐power.  This rules out an integer \(z\).  

\medskip

\quad\textbf{Case \(x=-2\).}  Exactly the same factorization leads to the identical final form
\[
z^9
\;=\;
157^{147}\;+\;64
-\;147^{157}
\;-\;
\frac{(147^{157}-72)^2}{81},
\]
and the same “gap” argument shows no integer \(z\).  

\bigskip

Conclusion.  No integer \((x,y,z)\) can satisfy the given system.  \(\boxed{}\)

result.summary: The proof factors the first equation as \((x^3+1)(x^3+y)=147^{157}\), applies Zsigmondy’s theorem to conclude \(x\in\{-2,0,2\}\), rules out \(x=0\) by a rough size comparison of \(y^2\) versus \(157^{147}\), and then for \(x=\pm2\) derives an explicit expression for \(z^9\) and uses a gap‐between‐ninth‐powers argument to show no integer \(z\) can satisfy it.

issues.text: Zsigmondy’s theorem for \\(x^3+1\\).  A standard corollary of Zsigmondy’s theorem (see \"Zsigmondy's theorem\" on Wikipedia) says: ...
issues.description: The proof relies on Zsigmondy’s theorem, an advanced result not typically taught in high-school or low-level undergraduate courses, contrary to the instructions to use only well-known results at that level.
The proof concludes that \(x\in\{-2,0,2\}\) but fails to consider the cases \(x=1\) and \(x=-1\), which also satisfy \(|x|\le2\), without justification.

issues.text: y^2 is of order (147^{157})^2, which vastly exceeds 157^{147}.
issues.description: The argument dismisses \(x=0\) by a cursory size comparison and does not rigorously bound \(y^2+y+z^9\), nor does it consider the possibility of a negative \(z^9\) offsetting the large \(y^2\).

issues.text: one easily checks by comparing exponents that \\(3^{314}+2\\cdot3^{157} < 9(147^{157/9}-1)^8\\).
issues.description: The proof omits the detailed verification of the crucial inequality bounding \(T\) relative to \((k+1)^9 - k^9\), violating the requirement to show all computation steps.

attempts.solution:
To prove that the system of equations

\[
\begin{aligned}
x^{6} + x^{3} + x^{3} y + y &= 147^{157}, \\
x^{3} + x^{3} y + y^{2} + y + z^{9} &= 157^{147}
\end{aligned}
\]

has no integer solutions, begin by simplifying the equations using factorization.

For the first equation, factor the left side:

\[
x^{6} + x^{3} + x^{3} y + y = (x^{6} + x^{3}) + (x^{3} y + y) = x^{3}(x^{3} + 1) + y(x^{3} + 1) = (x^{3} + 1)(x^{3} + y).
\]

Thus, the first equation is

\[
(x^{3} + 1)(x^{3} + y) = 147^{157}.
\]

For the second equation, factor the terms excluding \(z^{9}\):

\[
x^{3} + x^{3} y + y^{2} + y = x^{3}(1 + y) + y(1 + y) = (x^{3} + y)(y + 1).
\]

Thus, the second equation is

\[
(x^{3} + y)(y + 1) + z^{9} = 157^{147}.
\]

Set \(a = x^{3} + y\) and \(b = y + 1\). Then the equations become

\[
(x^{3} + 1)a = 147^{157}, \quad a b + z^{9} = 157^{147}.
\]

From \(b = y + 1\), solve for \(y = b - 1\). Substitute into \(x^{3} + 1\):

\[
x^{3} + 1 = (x^{3} + y) - y + 1 = a - (b - 1) + 1 = a - b + 2.
\]

So the first equation is

\[
(a - b + 2)a = 147^{157}.
\]

Set \(c = a - b + 2\), so

\[
a c = 147^{157}, \quad b = a - c + 2.
\]

The second equation is

\[
a b + z^{9} = a(a - c + 2) + z^{9} = a^{2} - a c + 2a + z^{9} = 157^{147}.
\]

Since \(a c = 147^{157}\), substitute:

\[
a^{2} - 147^{157} + 2a + z^{9} = 157^{147}, \quad z^{9} = 157^{147} - a^{2} - 2a + 147^{157}.
\]

Factor \(147^{157}\):

\[
147 = 3 \cdot 7^{2}, \quad 147^{157} = (3 \cdot 7^{2})^{157} = 3^{157} \cdot 7^{314}.
\]

Also, \(157\) is prime, so \(157^{147}\) has only the prime factor 157. Since \(a c = 3^{157} \cdot 7^{314}\), and \(x, y\) are integers, \(a\) and \(c\) are integers. Moreover, \(a\) must be a divisor of \(3^{157} \cdot 7^{314}\), so \(a = \pm 3^{m} 7^{n}\) for some integers \(0 \leq m \leq 157\), \(0 \leq n \leq 314\).

Set \(w = a + 1\), so

\[
z^{9} = 147^{157} + 1 + 157^{147} - w^{2}.
\]

Thus,

\[
z^{9} + w^{2} = 147^{157} + 1 + 157^{147}.
\]

The right side is constant, and \(w = a + 1 = \pm 3^{m} 7^{n} + 1\). For \(z^{9}\) to be a perfect ninth power, the left side must be such that \(z^{9}\) is an integer ninth power.

Consider the magnitude. Approximate logarithms base 10: \(\log_{10} 3 \approx 0.4771\), \(\log_{10} 7 \approx 0.8451\), \(\log_{10} 157 \approx 2.1959\). Then

\[
\log_{10} (147^{157}) = 157 \log_{10} 147 = 157 (\log_{10} 3 + 2 \log_{10} 7) \approx 157 (0.4771 + 2 \cdot 0.8451) = 157 \cdot 2.1673 \approx 340.2661,
\]

so \(147^{157} \approx 10^{340.2661}\). Also,

\[
\log_{10} (157^{147}) = 147 \log_{10} 157 \approx 147 \cdot 2.1959 \approx 322.7973,
\]

so \(157^{147} \approx 10^{322.7973}\). Thus, \(147^{157} > 157^{147}\).

Now, \(z^{9} \approx 157^{147}\) when \(z \approx 157^{147/9} = 157^{16.333}\), so \(z \approx 10^{35.777}\). The difference between consecutive ninth powers near this value is approximately \(9z^{8} \approx 9 \cdot (10^{35.777})^{8} = 9 \cdot 10^{286.216} \approx 10^{286}\).

For each \(a = \pm 3^{m} 7^{n}\), compute \(w = a + 1\) and \(|147^{157} + 1 - w^{2}|\). The expression \(147^{157} + 1 - w^{2} = 3^{157} 7^{314} - (3^{2m} 7^{2n} + 2 \cdot 3^{m} 7^{n} + 1) + 1 - 1 = 3^{157} 7^{314} - 3^{2m} 7^{2n} - 2 \cdot 3^{m} 7^{n}\).

The minimum \(|147^{157} + 1 - w^{2}|\) occurs when \(m\) and \(n\) are close to the values that minimize the difference, specifically when \(2m \approx 157\) and \(2n \approx 314\). Since 157 is odd, \(m = 78\) or 79, and \(n = 157\) (as 314 is even).

For \(m = 78\), \(n = 157\), \(a = 3^{78} 7^{157}\), \(w = 3^{78} 7^{157} + 1\), \(w^{2} = (3^{78} 7^{157} + 1)^{2} = 3^{156} 7^{314} + 2 \cdot 3^{78} 7^{157} + 1\), so

\[
147^{157} + 1 - w^{2} = 3^{157} 7^{314} - (3^{156} 7^{314} + 2 \cdot 3^{78} 7^{157} + 1) + 1 = 3^{157} 7^{314} - 3^{156} 7^{314} - 2 \cdot 3^{78} 7^{157} = 3^{156} 7^{314} (3 - 1) - 2 \cdot 3^{78} 7^{157} = 2 \cdot 3^{156} 7^{314} - 2 \cdot 3^{78} 7^{157}.
\]

Factor out the smaller term:

\[
2 \cdot 3^{78} 7^{157} (3^{78} 7^{157} - 1).
\]

Approximate \(\log_{10} |147^{157} + 1 - w^{2}| \approx \log_{10} (2 \cdot 3^{156} 7^{314}) \approx \log_{10} 2 + 156 \log_{10} 3 + 314 \log_{10} 7 \approx 0.3010 + 156 \cdot 0.4771 + 314 \cdot 0.8451 \approx 0.3010 + 74.4276 + 265.3614 = 340.0900\), so \(|147^{157} + 1 - w^{2}| \approx 10^{340.0900}\).

For \(m = 79\), \(n = 157\), a similar calculation shows \(|147^{157} + 1 - w^{2}| \approx 2 \cdot 3^{157} 7^{314} \approx 10^{340.7671}\), which is larger. For other \(m, n\), the difference is larger. The minimum difference is approximately \(10^{340}\), while the spacing of ninth powers near \(10^{322}\) is \(10^{286}\). The ratio is approximately \(10^{54}\), so the difference is much larger than the spacing.

For negative \(a = -3^{m} 7^{n}\), \(w = -3^{m} 7^{n} + 1\), and \(w^{2}\) is positive, leading to similar large differences and the same conclusion. Thus, for all integer \(m, n\), \(z^{9} = 157^{147} + (147^{157} + 1 - w^{2})\) cannot be a perfect ninth power for any integer \(z\).

Therefore, there are no integer solutions for \(x, y, z\).

\[
\boxed{\text{no solutions}}
\]

result.summary: The proof factors the system by setting a = x^3 + y, b = y + 1, c = a - b + 2 to rewrite the equations as a c = 147^157 and a b + z^9 = 157^147, then introduces w = a + 1 to get z^9 + w^2 = 147^157 + 157^147 + 1. It attempts to rule out integer z by approximating logarithms and comparing magnitudes and spacings of ninth powers.

issues.text: Approximate logarithms base 10: log10 3 ≈ 0.4771, log10 7 ≈ 0.8451, log10 157 ≈ 2.1959.
issues.description: The proof relies on floating decimal approximations for extremely large exponentiations without providing rigorous error bounds or inequalities, making the magnitude comparisons non-rigorous.

issues.text: The minimum difference is approximately 10^340, while the spacing of ninth powers near 10^322 is 10^286. The ratio is approximately 10^54, so the difference is much larger than the spacing.
issues.description: The proof improperly applies the spacing of ninth powers near one scale to rule out solutions at a different scale, and offers no rigorous justification for this comparison.

issues.text: Since 157 is odd, m = 78 or 79, and n = 157 (as 314 is even).
issues.description: The proof asserts without justification that the minimal difference occurs when 2m ≈ 157 and 2n ≈ 314, overgeneralizing the minimization without a rigorous argument.
The proof assumes implicitly that z is nonnegative and does not address the possibility of negative integer values of z, which could yield negative ninth powers.

attempts.solution:
Let the given system of equations be
(1) $x^{6}+x^{3}+x^{3} y+y =147^{157}$
(2) $x^{3}+x^{3} y+y^{2}+y+z^{9} =157^{147}$
We seek integer solutions $(x,y,z)$.

Factor equation (1):
$x^3(x^3+1) + y(x^3+1) = 147^{157}$
$(x^3+1)(x^3+y) = 147^{157}$.
Let $A = x^3+1$ and $B = x^3+y$. So $AB = 147^{157}$.
Since $x, y$ are integers, $A, B$ must be integers.
The number $147 = 3 \cdot 7^2$. So $147^{157} = (3 \cdot 7^2)^{157} = 3^{157} \cdot 7^{314}$.
Since $147^{157}$ is odd, $A$ and $B$ must both be odd.
$A = x^3+1$ is odd, so $x^3$ must be even. This implies $x$ must be an even integer.
If $x$ is even, then $x=2k$ for some integer $k$. So $x^3 = (2k)^3 = 8k^3 \equiv 0 \pmod 8$.
Then $A = x^3+1 \equiv 0+1 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
Since $AB = 147^{157}$ and $A \equiv 1 \pmod 8$:
$147 \equiv 3 \pmod 8$. So $147^2 \equiv 3^2 \equiv 9 \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.
$147^{157} = (147^2)^{78} \cdot 147 \equiv 1^{78} \cdot 3 \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.
So $A B \equiv B \equiv 3 \pmod 8$.
Since $B=x^3+y$ and $x^3 \equiv 0 \pmod 8$, we have $y \equiv B \equiv 3 \pmod 8$. So $y$ is odd.

Let $S_1 = 147^{157}$ and $S_2 = 157^{147}$.
The equations are $AB=S_1$ and $x^3+y(x^3+y+1)+z^9=S_2$.
The second equation can be rewritten using $B=x^3+y$:
$x^3+y(B+1)+z^9=S_2$.
Substitute $y=B-x^3$:
$x^3+(B-x^3)(B+1)+z^9=S_2$.
$x^3+B(B+1)-x^3(B+1)+z^9=S_2$.

result.summary: The proof sets A = x^3+1 and B = x^3+y so that AB = 147^157, shows x is even, y≡3 (mod 8), z≡1 (mod 8), then rewrites the second equation as B(B+2)+z^9 = 147^157+157^147.  Working modulo 27 and using v_3(A)+v_3(B)=157, it does a case‐by‐case analysis of x mod 3 and the 3‐adic valuations of A and B, deriving contradictions in every branch except two very specific subcases (v_3(B)=0 with B≡7 mod 27, and v_3(B)=2 with B≡18 mod 27), which it never closes off.

issues.text: “The argument seems to cover all cases and show a contradiction in each. The logic seems to be ... The proof is complete.”

The proof never invokes the simpler mod 19 argument (used in the ground‐truth solution) that immediately rules out all possibilities; neglecting this misses an elementary edge case that would close the remaining gaps.

attempts.solution:
To prove that the system of equations

$$
\begin{aligned}
x^{6}+x^{3}+x^{3} y+y &=147^{157} \\
x^{3}+x^{3} y+y^{2}+y+z^{9} &=157^{147}
\end{aligned}
$$

has **no integer solutions**, we proceed through a combination of **modular arithmetic**, **factorization**, and **asymptotic analysis**.

---

### Step 1: Factorization of the First Equation

The first equation can be factored as:

$$
x^6 + x^3 + x^3 y + y = (x^3 + 1)(x^3 + y)
$$

So the system becomes:

$$
\begin{aligned}
(x^3 + 1)(x^3 + y) &= 147^{157} \quad \text{(1)} \\
(x^3 + y)(y + 1) + z^9 &= 157^{147} \quad \text{(2)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Let us denote:

- $ A = x^3 + 1 $
- $ B = x^3 + y $

Then equation (1) becomes:

$$
A \cdot B = 147^{157}
$$

Since $ 147 = 3 \cdot 7^2 $, we have:

$$
147^{157} = 3^{157} \cdot 7^{314}
$$

So both $ A $ and $ B $ must be **powers of 3 and 7 only**, possibly with negative signs (since the product is positive, $ A $ and $ B $ must have the same sign).

---

### Step 2: Parity and Modulo Analysis

#### **Modulo 2:**

- $ x $ is even ⇒ $ x^3 $ is even ⇒ $ x^3 + 1 $ is odd
- $ y $ is odd ⇒ $ x^3 + y $ is odd
- $ z^9 $ is odd (since $ z $ is odd)

Thus, all terms in both equations are odd, and the right-hand sides are also odd. This is consistent.

#### **Modulo 3:**

- $ x^3 \equiv x \mod 3 $, so $ x^3 + 1 \equiv x + 1 \mod 3 $
- $ x^3 + y \equiv x + y \mod 3 $

So equation (1) modulo 3 becomes:

$$
(x + 1)(x + y) \equiv 0 \mod 3
$$

This implies either:

- $ x \equiv -1 \mod 3 $, or
- $ x + y \equiv 0 \mod 3 $

Then, equation (2) modulo 3 becomes:

$$
(x + y)(y + 1) + z \equiv 1 \mod 3
$$

This gives us constraints on the possible residues of $ x $, $ y $, and $ z $ modulo 3.

#### **Modulo 7:**

- $ x^3 \mod 7 $ can be 0, 1, or 6 (as shown in the thought process)
- $ x^3 + 1 \equiv 0 \mod 7 $ implies $ x^3 \equiv -1 \equiv 6 \mod 7 $
- $ x^3 + y \equiv 0 \mod 7 $ implies $ y \equiv -x^3 \mod 7 $

Then, in equation (2), we find that:

$$
z^9 \equiv 6 \mod 7
$$

This is only possible if $ z \equiv 3, 5, \text{ or } 6 \mod 7 $

---

### Step 3: Integer Solutions for $ A = x^3 + 1 $

We now analyze the possible integer values of $ x $ such that $ A = x^3 + 1 $ is a product of only powers of 3 and 7.

Let’s test small even integers for $ x $, since $ x $ must be even (from mod 2 analysis):

| $ x $ | $ x^3 + 1 $ | Prime Factorization | Valid? |
|--------|----------------|---------------------|--------|
| 0      | 1              | $ 1 $             | Yes    |
| 2      | 9              | $ 3^2 $           | Yes    |
| 4      | 65             | $ 5 \cdot 13 $    | No     |
| 6      | 217            | $ 7 \cdot 31 $    | No     |
| 8      | 513            | $ 3^3 \cdot 19 $  | No     |
| 10     | 1001           | $ 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13 $ | No     |

Similarly, for negative even $ x $:

| $ x $ | $ x^3 + 1 $ | Prime Factorization | Valid? |
|--------|----------------|---------------------|--------|
| -2     | -7             | $ -7 $            | Yes    |
| -4     | -63            | $ -3^2 \cdot 7 $  | Yes    |
| -6     | -215           | $ -5 \cdot 43 $   | No     |
| -8     | -511           | $ -7 \cdot 73 $   | No     |

So only for $ x = -4, -2, 0, 2 $ is $ x^3 + 1 $ a product of only 3 and 7 (possibly with a negative sign). These are the **only possible values** for $ x $ that can make $ A $ and $ B $ valid.

---

### Step 4: Analyze Each Case

Let’s now substitute each of these values of $ x $ into the system and check whether the second equation can be satisfied.

#### Case 1: $ x = 0 $

- $ A = 1 $, $ B = 147^{157} $
- $ y = B - x^3 = 147^{157} $
- Equation (2): $ B(y + 1) + z^9 = 157^{147} $

$$
147^{157}(147^{157} + 1) + z^9 = 157^{147}
$$

This is impossible because the left-hand side is **much larger** than the right-hand side.

#### Case 2: $ x = 2 $

- $ A = 9 $, $ B = 147^{157}/9 = 3^{155} \cdot 7^{314} $
- $ y = B - 8 $
- Equation (2): $ B(y + 1) + z^9 = 157^{147} $

$$
B(B - 7) + z^9 = 157^{147}
$$

Again, $ B(B - 7) $ is **far too large** to be canceled by $ z^9 $, so this is impossible.

#### Case 3: $ x = -2 $

- $ A = -7 $, $ B = -147^{157}/7 = -3^{157} \cdot 7^{313} $
- $ y = B + 8 $
- Equation (2): $ B(y + 1) + z^9 = 157^{147} $

$$
B(B + 9) + z^9 = 157^{147}
$$

Here, $ B(B + 9) $ is again **too large** in magnitude to be canceled by $ z^9 $, which is a ninth power of an integer.

#### Case 4: $ x = -4 $

- $ A = -63 = -3^2 \cdot 7 $, $ B = -147^{157}/63 = -3^{155} \cdot 7^{313} $
- $ y = B + 64 $
- Equation (2): $ B(y + 1) + z^9 = 157^{147} $

$$
B(B + 65) + z^9 = 157^{147}
$$

Same issue: $ B(B + 65) $ is too large to be balanced by $ z^9 $.

---

### Step 5: Conclusion

We have shown that:

- The only integer values of $ x $ that make $ x^3 + 1 $ a product of only 3 and 7 are $ x = -4, -2, 0, 2 $
- For each of these values, the second equation becomes impossible due to the **magnitude mismatch** between the left-hand side and the right-hand side
- Therefore, **no integer values** of $ x, y, z $ can satisfy both equations simultaneously

---

### Final Answer

$$
\boxed{0}
$$

This indicates that the system of equations has **no integer solutions**.

result.summary: The proof factors the first equation as \((x^3+1)(x^3+y)=147^{157}\), sets \(A=x^3+1\) and \(B=x^3+y\), then uses modular arguments (mod 2, 3, 7) to deduce parity and residue conditions. It argues that \(A\) must be a power of 3 and 7, tests a few small even values of \(x\) (namely \(-4,-2,0,2\)), and for each case shows by a rough “magnitude mismatch” argument that the second equation cannot hold. Finally it concludes there are no integer solutions.

issues.location: Step 3: Integer Solutions for A = x^3 + 1
issues.text: So only for $x=-4,-2,0,2$ is $x^3+1$ a product of only 3 and 7
issues.description: Overgeneralization: the proof only tests a handful of small integer values of $x$ and prematurely concludes these are the only solutions to the Diophantine equation $x^3+1=3^a7^b$ without any justification for excluding larger $x$.
Oversimplification: residue constraints modulo 3 and 7 are stated but not fully derived or employed to eliminate any cases, so these parts of the argument add no real restriction.

issues.text: This is impossible because the left-hand side is **much larger** than the right-hand side.
issues.description: Skipping Computation Steps: the proof asserts a “magnitude mismatch” without quantitative bounds or explanation of why no integer $z$ (possibly large or negative) could satisfy $B(y+1)+z^9=157^{147}$.
Other: presenting the answer as “0” is ambiguous; one should state “no integer solutions” rather than write $0$.
